Award.AwardTitle: Evolutionary origins of female katydid preferences for specific characteristics of male vocalizations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the fundamental biological question of the evolution of novel traits, i.e. traits that do not have obvious precursors. The PIs use a novel behavioral trait, namely the female preference for leading calls, to study the mechanisms that lead to the evolution of this trait. Using a diverse study system (Neoconocephalus katydids), the PIs use a broad range of experiments to test all relevant factors that could potentially contribute to the evolution of the novel trait. Experimental methods include behavioral tests, breeding experiments, bioacoustic analyses and neurobiological analyses. All experiments will be conducted comparatively among up to ten species.

The results will produce arguably the most complete picture of the evolution of a novel trait to date, allowing critical evaluation of multiple adaptive and non-adaptive hypotheses. This study will be a major contribution to the understanding of the origins of biodiversity at both the physiological and evolutionary levels. Understanding the origins of biodiversity may in turn contribute to the preservation of biodiversity, by furthering the understanding of the role that climate and other environmental variables impact trait expression.

The broader impacts of this study include not only potential contributions to preserving biodiversity, but also educating future scientists. Four graduate students and multiple undergraduate students will be trained. The breadth of approaches makes this project ideal for training students in the integrative study of complex biological problems. The PIs also reach out to other biology faculty at regional 2- and 4-year colleges through workshops on integrating current research approaches into the undergraduate curriculum, and by building a community of biology educators across multiple institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many insects, such as Neoconocephaluskatydids, use acoustic communication to bring males and females together for mating: males typically call and female approach them guided by their calls. Females typically have preferences for calls of their own species and, in some cases, for specific call traits within their species.

Male calls and female preferences for them are among the most diverse traits in these insects; the acoustic communication system is an important factor in the origin and maintenance of their biodiversity. The goal of this project was to understand the mechanisms that lead to the evolution of the female preference for leading calls in Neoconocephaluskatydids. This is a widespread preference among insects and frogs which produce calls with rhythmically repeated chirps or notes: when two chirps overlap in time, females prefer the leading chirp.  In Neoconocephaluskatydids, some species possess a strong leader preference but other species do not, providing an opportunity to examine the evolutionary origin of this preference. 

The PIs studied this question with an integrative approach that  brought together multiple components of importance, including behavior, genetics, and physiology. 

Behavioral experiments revealed that of the species with chirped calls, two possessed the preference for leading calls while several others did not. Species with continuous calls (i.e. where leader/follower relationships never occur in nature) did not show this preference, when given the choice.

Neurophysiological measurements demonstrated that the encoding of leading and following calls did not differ among species with and without the preference: both the leading and following signals were encoded equally. Taken together, these results indicate that the preference for the leading call is not the outcome of a pre-existing bias of the sensory system, but evolved newly in the two species that possess the preference.

In selective breeding experiments, females that mated with leading callers had larger and heavier offspring than females that mated with following callers. This suggests that the preference for leading males increases female fitness, i.e. females with this preference have more or better offspring than females without it. However, the sons of leading males were not more likely to be leaders, indicating that leader/follower status of males was not heritable.

Analyses of the evolutionary history of these traits revealed that the preference for leading calls evolved at least twice in this genus. As several species with chirped calls lack this preference, the preference likely evolved after chirped calls evolved from ancestral continuous calls. Molecular clock analysis revealed that the diversity of Neoconocephaluscalls and female preferences evolved since the last glacial maximum, i.e. in the last 10-20,000 years. 

These findings lead to the following conclusions:

-   The preference for leading calls is not the outcome of a preexisting bias of the hearing system, but evolved driven by benefits for females mating with leading males.

-   Female preferences may evolve even for non-heritable male traits, if the preference results in a benefit for the female.

-   Behavioral changes, such as new calls and new female preferences, may evolve rapidly in changing environments.

-   Neoconocephaluskatydids provide an excellent opportunity to study evolutionary responses to rapid environmental changes, including the genetic underpinnings of these responses to environmental change.

 

This project had a strong training and outreach component: Seven graduate students (4 PhD, 3 MA) and multiple undergraduate students were trained and completed their degrees; the four PhD students have positions with educational/teaching focus at 2- and 4- year colleges and universities. The PIs taught several curriculum development workshops about teaching evolution for faculty at regional 2-and 4-year colleges. A biodiversity/ecology/evolution curriculum for high school biology classes was developed based on the acoustic communication of katydids that can be heard in most schoolyards in the US. The PI organized the national meeting of the Animal Behavior Society in 2016, including significant outreach programming that impacted about 1300 people.
